posts.post_content:
The power of ice and snow is often represented by red (snow is on top of mountains too), especially in Kamigawa.  
  
[Glacial Ray](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Glacial Ray), [Frostwielder](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Frostwielder), [Frostling](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Frostling), [Frost Ogre](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Frost Ogre), and the Yamabushi shaman's techniques are based on ice as well, like [Kumano, Master Yamabushi](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kumano, Master Yamabushi).
posts.html:
The power of ice and snow is often represented by red (snow is on top of mountains too), especially in Kamigawa.

Glacial Ray, Frostwielder, Frostling, Frost Ogre, and the Yamabushi shaman's techniques are based on ice as well, like Kumano, Master Yamabushi.

Posted By: Dragon_Nut (2/6/2011 8:03:44 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I pay close attention to Japanese myth and legend and I was surprised that Yuki-Onna ended up being Red. but from a story perspective she was a cold hearted vengeful spirit, I guess thats her red aspect. the ability to destroy artifacts repeatedly wasn't too much of a concern back in Kamigawa. The cast of 4 mana after bouncing her was a bit steep, considering what Arcane and spirit spells were available at the time.

posts.post_content: My favorite Japanese mythical creature, and one of the better 'Onna'. I am a bit confused as to the artifact destruction. Yes, its a red thing, but it just doesn't match the flavor of the card in my opinion. Ice, snow and blizzards have never been associated with artifact destruction in Magic, and in real life myths of the Yuki-Onna they spend more time doing things like abducting children.
